awd_titl_txt: Nanofibrils: Quest to the Origin of Spider Silk's Strength, Toughness, and Formation
awd_abstract_narration:
Nanofibrils: Quest to the Origin of Spider Silk?s Strength, Toughness, and Formation

Non-Technical Abstract: 
Spider silk is an intriguing material that has fascinated researchers and laymen alike. Featuring outstanding strength and toughness, spider silk outperforms some of the best man-made materials. These properties are intimately related to the highly sophisticated structure of silk, revealing different features when studied at increasing magnifications. Nanofibrils have recently been identified to play a key role in this structure; their outstanding properties will thus be at the center of this project and will be studied in terms of their structure, properties, and functions. Several of the most advanced microscopy and spectroscopy techniques will be combined to reveal the internal structure of the nanofibrils, with the ultimate goal of obtaining a complete understanding of silk fibers across all length scales, starting at the molecular level and reaching to the size of the entire silk fiber. One of the goals of this project is to provide the foundations for future efforts to synthesize outstanding materials inspired by spider silk. Because of the critical importance of nanofibrils, the project will study the conditions of their formation, ultimately to enable the fabrication of synthetic fibers made of such nanofibrils. In this pursuit, several graduate and undergraduate students will acquire specialized training in materials testing and characterization, high-resolution imaging, materials manipulation at the nanoscale and computer modeling. The project includes multiple outreach activities to bring this exciting spider silk project to students in elementary, middle, and high schools with the goal of motivating them to pursue careers in STEM disciplines.

Technical Abstract: 
This research project studies a broad range of aspects of silk nanofibrils, which have recently been identified as key structural and functional elements in silk fibers. To fully reveal the hierarchical structure of silk fibers across all length scales, a broad range of imaging techniques will be employed, including atomic force microscopy, scanning electron microscopy, and transmission electron microscopy. These techniques will be complemented by spectroscopic and inverse-space characterization methods, including vibrational spectroscopy, solid-state nuclear magnetic resonance, and X-ray diffraction. Finite element analysis will be employed to develop a coherent model of the mechanical properties of silk fibers, with the ultimate goal of relating the observed macroscopic performance of a silk fiber to its hierarchical structure across the length scales. Because nanofibrils are so critical to the performance of silk fibers, this project will also study their conditions of formation. Molecular self-assembly of silk proteins is a very promising route to bottom-up fabrication of silk nanofibrils and will be employed in this project to determine the most critical parameters of nanofibril formation. The knowledge gained in this project will be critical to future efforts to synthesize outstanding materials inspired by spider silk: the hierarchical structure determined in the project will serve as a template for materials synthesis; the self-assembly mechanisms revealed by the project can be employed to ultimately realize these hierarchical structures starting at the molecular scale. The project includes multiple outreach activities to bring this exciting spider silk project to students in elementary, middle, and high schools with the goal of motivating them to pursue careers in STEM disciplines.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Spider silk has impressive mechanical properties, featuring five times the specific strength of steel, and five times the toughness of Kevlar. In nature, it is produced fully sustainably, in an environmentally benign way. Moreover, it entirely consists of a protein that, although foreign to the human body, does not trigger an immune response, and thus, can be widely used for medical applications. This unique and impressive set of properties makes spider silk the prototype of a multi-functional, sustainable performance material based on proteins for the 21st-century. To produce this material synthetically, one needs to understand both its complex, hierarchical structure better, as well as the processes needed to turn it into this structure.

This project has made major contributions to revealing the hierarchical structure and properties of spider silk at multiple length scales, as well as its formation. The attached overview Figure 1 features the hierarchical structure of spider silk, highlighting the different types of structures observed at different length scales. Cob web—centimeter scale (a), web loops—100 μm scale (b), silk ribbons—10 μm wide (c), nanofibrillar ribbon structure—10 nm scale (d), nanofibrillar internal structure—few nm scale (e), protein secondary structure—1 nm scale (f), and protein primary structure—molecular scale (g).

Most importantly, this work has unambigously shown that many important spider silks entirely consist of straight, long, parallel, uniform nanofibrils, about 10–20 nm in diameter. In other words, a single spider silk fiber, usually ten times thinner than a human hair, consists of thousands of even finer nanofibrils. This is highlighted in Figure 2, where a golden orb weaver spider is shown (left), which was then “exfoliated” into countless nanofibrils (false-colored scanning electron micrograph, center). This led to the nanofibrillar model of the silk fiber (right). This project also showed that these nanofibrils are bonded together relatively weakly, from which it follows that the impressive properties of spider silk are already present at a level of an individual nanofibril. This is a major breakthrough in the field, because this means that one only needs to understand an individual nanofibril and how it is made, in order to be able to understand spider silk and to replicate it.

The project then went on to develop new experimental techniques, which allowed the researchers to reveal the molecular organization of the silk protein inside the nanofibrils. What the team found was that the protein molecules are present in several different structural configurations, including curled-up, screw-like, helical structures, and small, crystalline sheets. Based on this deep level of understanding of the molecular structure of spider silk, one can now try to relate this structure to the behavior and properties of silk in a rigorous manner. This project then also made huge strides in understanding the formation process of these nanofibrils, and the researchers even accomplished to make synthetic spider silk nanofibrils featuring a shape virtually indistinguishable from natural spider silk nanofibrils. Taken together, these new insights represent a significant step toward the ability of synthesizing spider silk.

At larger length scale, the project also discovered interesting adhesion phenomena between the ribbon-shaped spider silk fibers of the brown recluse spider, which leads to surprisingly strong bonding. This approach was then used to make a new type of material consisting entirely of ribbon-like fibers arranged in a particular way to trigger this strong adhesion. This led to a new type of composite material, which featured significantly enhanced strength and toughness. This system is currently pursued as a patent.

During the research carried out in this project, a significant number of undergraduate, graduate and high school students were trained in many important professional skills, including experimental techniques, data analysis, and scientific writing. This work included several underrepresented groups and thus broadened participation in science.
